newsitem.title: BOSNIA: Expected Bosnia currency to be convertible - cbanker.
newsitem.headline: Expected Bosnia currency to be convertible - cbanker.

text.p: The yet-to-be-created currency for post-war Bosnia will be convertible for at least six years once it is introduced, Sarajevo's daily Dnevni Avaz newspaper quoted the national bank governor as saying on Thursday.

"The quantity of Bosnian currency in circulation will directly depend on the country's foreign currency reserves, and the foreign exchange rate will be fixed for the next six years," national bank governor Kasim Omicevic told the newspaper.

The national banks of Bosnia's two constitutent entities -- its Moslem-Croat federation and its Serb republic -- will cease to exist once a new Central Bank is established. Omisevic is governor of the existing federation bank.
The new Central Bank of Bosnia-Hercegovina will be created once the results of September 14 country-wide elections have been certified.
Under the terms of the Dayton pace agreement, the new central bank will have authority to issue currency and formulate monetary policy.
Omicevic could not say what the new currency would be called. A variety of currencies are now used in different parts of Bosnia, with the German mark being the only one accepted everywhere.

The Bosnian dinar is accepted on Moslem-controlled territory and the Croatian kuna is used in Bosnian Croat-held areas. Bank notes from the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia circulate in Serb-dominated parts of Bosnia.
